comment.author: 21336483@N03
comment._content:
As the Library of Congress, you provide an invaluable service by posting so many of the archival photos of the Titanic on Flickr.

PS I have my own large Titanic model,1:200 scale or 4.4 ft or 1.35 metres long in a diorama, which shows the waves, bow and stern wakes, and clouds.

I think you'll like it!

I've added you to my favs and as a contact.


Thanks


Richard

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Their real names were Michel and Edmond Navratil, ages 4 and 2. They were reunited with their mother, who was in la France. Michel, the older boy, lived to be 92. More in the comments under this Bain/LOC photo: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2535973345/ [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2535973345/] Another Bain/LOC photo of the tiny Titanic survivors: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163880148/]

comment.author: 75477453@N04
comment._content:
I wrote a poem to commemorate this tragic event that took place 100 years ago. I am right now reading a book called " A Night to Remember by Walter Lord " It's about the final hours before the Titanic sank. 

Here is my poem :)! 

Oh Titanic ! 
Oh Titanic we morn for thee, 
we remember the old days you us to see ,
 sailing the deep blue see.

You were but the jewel
the crown of England
waiting on the sea floor with ghostly cheers.
People rushed to get upon you, 
not knowing the doom that laid before you.

Men , Mother, Children forgetting to bring a life boat,
rushed to their rooms searching for love ones.
Children crying holding their tummies,
well mothers cry for their love ones that were dying.

By Ethan

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Next time you get inspired to write a "poem," resist the impulse.

comment.author: 75477453@N04
comment._content: There was no resiting the impulse... it just came from my heart and the way you feel about the event that took place 100 years ago. So sad.
